data.title: Felix M. Warburg Papers
data.text:
Felix M. (Moritz) Warburg was born in Hamburg, Germany on 14 January 1871 to Charlotte Esther Oppenheim Warburg and Moritz Moses Warburg. He came to the United States in 1894. Warburg was a partner in the New York banking firm, Kuhn, Loeb and Co. His chief interests, however, were in philanthropy, education, and culture. Warburg was a key figure in the German-Jewish elite of the early 20th century American Jewish community. Warburg was involved in organizations such as the Jewish Agency, the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the American Jewish Committee. He was a trustee of Columbia University in New York City, a governor of Hebrew University in Jerusalem, and a director of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

In 1895, Warburg married Frieda Schiff, daughter of Kuhn, Loeb & Co. senior partner Jacob Schiff. They had five children: Carola, Frederick, Gerald, Paul, and Edward. Felix M. Warburg died on 20 October 1937 in New York City.

American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee Archives

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) Archives houses one of the most significant collections in the world for the study of modern Jewish history. Comprising the organizational records of JDC, the overseas rescue, relief, and rehabilitation arm of the American Jewish community, the archives includes over 3 miles of text documents, 100,000 photographs, a research library of more than 6,000 books, 1,100 audio recordings including oral histories, and a video collection. To search the JDC Archives' text-collections, click here.

SCOPE AND CONTENT NOTE top

The Felix M. Warburg Papers consist of records documenting the life and career of a New York financier and banker whose chief interests were in philanthropy, education, and culture. His papers reflect his activities and considerable contributions in these fields and consist of correspondence, addresses, records, minutes of various committee meetings, reports, and letterbooks. The span dates for the collection are 1910-1937.

The collection consists of two series:

A. Correspondence Files. 1910-1937.

B. Letterbooks. 1928-1932.

Series A is arranged chronologically by year. Within each year, files are arranged alphabetically by subject with ÂGeneral CorrespondenceÂ folders at the beginning of each year. Series B is also arranged chronologically by date within volumes.

Series A of the Felix M. Warburg Papers was originally inventoried in the Manuscript Catalog of the American Jewish Archives, published in 1971 (Volume 4), pages 263 through 510. Since that time, the numbering scheme of the boxes within the collection has changed; hence, researchers should be aware that numbers given in the printed Manuscript Catalog do not reflect current box numbers, but instead are typically a few boxes off. Please use the Manuscript Catalog Inventory of the Schiff collection in conjunction with the box and folder list below for research.
